== Defining ethics ==
 
According to Tomas Paul and Linda Elder of the [[Foundation for Critical Thinking]], "most people confuse ethics with behaving in accordance with social conventions, religious beliefs and the law", and don't treat ethics as a stand-alone concept.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite book |title= The Miniature Guide to Understanding the Foundations of Ethical Reasoning|edition= |last1= Paul|first1= Richard|last2= Elder|first2= Linda|year= 2006|publisher= Foundation for Critical Thinking Free Press|location= United States|isbn= 0-944583-17-2|page= np}}</ref> Paul and Elder define ethics as "a set of concepts and principles that guide us in determining what behavior helps or harms sentient creatures".<ref name="ReferenceA"/> The ''[[Cambridge Dictionary of Philosophy]]'' states that the word ethics is "commonly used interchangeably with '[[morality]]' ... and sometimes it is used more narrowly to mean the moral principles of a particular tradition, group or individual."<ref>John Deigh in Robert Audi (ed), ''The Cambridge Dictionary of Philosophy'', 1995.</ref>

Often ethics is defined as the systematic identification of wise and foolish behavior or decision making and is contrasted with [[political philosophy]] which attempts to understand what is just and unjust and what behavior should be criminalized.
     
The general meaning of '''ethics''': rational, optimal (''regarded as the best solution of the given options'') and appropriate decision brought on the basis of common sense.
